utterance.speaker: Originally aired
utterance.content: Sept 12 2006

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Mom! I’m thirsty.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: I just gave you water.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I want juice.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: It’s bedtime. Close your eyes and go to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Mom!

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: What do you want, Clance?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Oh. Hi, Dad.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Go to bed.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Can I turn the TV on?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: TV is only for the day.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I’ll keep the volume down; I just like the light.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Go to bed.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Dad, what if… what if they come to get me again?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Nobody is coming to get you, okay? Go to bed, now.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Come on Clancy, it’s time to get up. I guess he’s already up.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Well, that’s a first.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: I’ll, uh, I’ll see if he needs breakfast. Hey, Clance, you hungry? Hon, he’s not down here!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: You sure? Clancy? Clancy? Clancy! Where are you? Sweetie, are you hiding?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Clancy!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Where is he?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Clancy!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Clancy!

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: You’re going to be in big trouble when I find you!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Honey, come out right now! Wherever you are, this is not funny!

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Clance!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Clancy!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ah. Where’s the sweat and the B.O? You’ve taken such pride bathing us in your personal musk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Showered at home.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And yet you’re earlier than usual.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is this an intervention? It’s a little late, since I’m not using drugs anymore. I am, however, still hooked on phonics.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you still did your morning run and showered at home you’d be later than usual.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thought of you in the shower.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How’s your leg? You seem to be favoring your left side.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was hanging down my right pant leg yesterday. Makes all the difference in the world.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’ve taken the stairs every day.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do I need a restraining order?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You slack on your rehab, the muscle will weaken, and your leg will hurt again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Looks like the ketamine treatment might not stick.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Or maybe we’ve made him depressed because we’re lying to him. Telling him he got that case wrong.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We didn’t hurt him. The pain isn’t –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He gets depressed, he stops exercising. He stops exercising, the muscle atrophies. The muscle atrophies, the pain returns.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe he stops exercising because the giant hole in his leg actually hurts.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The ketamine could work perfectly and he would still be back on his cane, popping Vicodin again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You can’t tell him. He got lucky; there was no medical –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He was right!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We tell him he was right, and we’re feeding his addiction. Without Vicodin, he’s only got one to focus on.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, he’s not going to OD on puzzles.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, it’s not going to hurt HIM. But he could just as easily have killed that patient. We have a tiny window of time here where House may be healthy enough to change and, based on that limp, the window’s closing fast.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kid is a product of an in vitro fertilization pregnancy. Had all his vaccinations, fractured his right ulna at age three, chicken pox at age five –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He ever get his feelings hurt? I’ll need to know that, too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You are 0 for 1 since you came back. You just want to make sure –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Rectal bleeding plus alien abduction fantasy is most likely sexual abuse. Penetration causes the bleed, trauma causes the fantasy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: ER ran a rape kit, found no evidence of tearing, semen, or pubic hairs.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe we should talk to the kid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why, in case he’s telling the truth? You’re a believer, aren’t you?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, I’m just not arrogant enough to think that of the 50 billion galaxies, 100 billion stars per galaxy, and 10 million billion planets in the universe that we’re the only ones with life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. But I’m guessing we’re the only ones who like shoving things through our back doors.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There is new research indicating a link between neurological problems and bleeding disorders.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Perfect. Especially if there were neurological problems.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What part of “hallucinating an alien abduction” isn’t neurological?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, why is that a hallucination?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What? You think the kid –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s having nightmares. Nightmares aren’t a symptom of anything, other than wanting to sleep with Mommy. Which just leaves us with one symptom: the bloody tuchas, which can easily be explained by a GI problem or a bleeding disorder. Check his coags with PT, PTT, and bleeding time. And prep him for endoscopies from above and below.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re going to make a tiny nick in your forearm, okay? And we’re going to time how long it takes for you to stop bleeding. Now, this is going to sting a little, so you might want to look the other way.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Are those windows locked?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Those windows don’t even open, they’re just here to let sunshine in.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Good, ‘cause they know I’m here.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Clancy, don’t bother the doctor with this stuff.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, it’s okay. How do they know you’re here?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: They put a chip in my neck so they can keep track of me. I can feel it back there.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Clancy, you know there is nothing back there.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: There is!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Let me see. Lean forward.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: And they have this other thing, and they put it in between these two ribs, always on this side, and then they move it around my insides. It hurts.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You know what, Clancy? I think I might have found the chip back there. And I think I might be able to get it out.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mm hmm. Okay, lean forwards. Now hold very still, okay? Got it!

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I’m seven, not three. All you did was pinch my neck.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His alien abduction story… the level of detail is... I don’t know where he gets it from. The parents say he doesn’t watch sci-fi, he doesn’t read comic books –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great! You do any of that medical stuff we talked about?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Upper and lower endoscopies were clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So it’s a simple bleeding disorder.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, blood tests were all normal. And he clotted in six minutes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So it’s a simple bleeding disorder and you screwed up the test.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I didn’t screw up the test!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So it’s a UFO, unidentified flowing orifice. Either you screwed up the test, or I screwed up my analysis of this case. If you screwed up, I don’t have to cry myself to sleep. It’s a simple bleeding disorder. Foreman, redo the test.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How could I screw up a simple bleeding time test?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Maybe you were abducted; lost time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kid’s got a bleeding disorder.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sure?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Had to stop the bleeding myself after 25 minutes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you’re saying Chase did screw up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or Foreman screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Big hand points to minutes. Maybe you got them mixed up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, snap! Foreman’s playing the dozens; you’re at a cultural disadvantage here. Take a few minutes to think up a witty retort.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So we have contradicting bleeding time tests. If we run labs to check his clotting factors we can confirm which one’s right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, testing, nice idea. Way better than trying to guess which doctor’s incompetent. Much better than the paperwork, too.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hey, Foreman. Your momma’s so fat, when her beeper goes off, people think she’s backing up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Where’s Clancy?

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: He’s asleep, he’s –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: House! Clancy’s gone missing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, no! Well, you take Alpha Centauri, Foreman can look on Tatooine, and Cameron can set up an intergalactic checkpoint. Let’s pray he hasn’t gone into hyperdrive! We’ll never catch him.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Clancy?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I had to go where there was no windows, so I could get the chip out, like you said!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I can feel it, I just can’t grab it –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Clancy, stop! There is no chip! We’re going to clean you up, and we’re going to go back to your room. You can’t do things like this. Your parents…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Results came back. The lab cannot identify the metal. They said it might not even be terrestrial.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you idiot! It’s titanium. Like from a surgical pin, like the kind the kid had inserted into his broken arm four years ago, nice medical history.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That pin was removed six months after –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what, a little piece broke off during removal.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Titanium is used to build nuclear subs, pieces don’t just break off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell that to the guys on the Kursk.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And how exactly did it get from his arm to the back of his neck?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Body attacks any foreign object. Inflammatory reaction could have eroded into a vein, fragment gets a free ride.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: To his lungs, maybe. Not his neck.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. An alien chip makes more sense. The real mystery is you didn’t actually screw up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I tripped. Kid carved a hole in the back of his neck, apparently didn’t bleed to death. Now that’s weird.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He clotted on his own?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure did. So first there was no bleeding disorder, then there was, now there’s not again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which is impossible.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or Foreman screwed up. Two out of three tests agree with my findings.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lucky for us, the fourth test will be the charm.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: So you’re just going to keep cutting him, until what?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This test is different. We’ll draw some blood and see if any clotting factors are low or missing.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: But why haven’t the other tests –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ve had three results that haven’t been consistent. One of them must be wrong.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or two of them.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Is it possible the problem isn’t his blood? It’s just psychological? I mean, he almost killed himself.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He wasn’t trying to hurt himself.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: No, he was just looking for an alien tracking device.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I have time for one more.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: I don’t blame you for spending extra time down here. Heard the Artist-Formerly-Known-as-Gimp is back upstairs. Oh, Dr. Cuddy wants that one.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s busy, I’ll take it. Oh, my God! You’re, uh, you’re okay!

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: Have we met?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I was one of your doctors. You were in a vegetative state when you left here last week.

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: Addison’s disease. All I needed was cortisol, and my brain turned on like a switch.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This is amazing!

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: Surprised you didn’t know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How would I know?

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: Not quite my old self yet. Baby steps, the doctors tell me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: With rehab you’ll do great. What hospital did you go to? How would I –

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: I want to have sex with my wife.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: And I was hoping that maybe you could –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Viagra. You’re here for Viagra?

utterance.speaker: Richard
utterance.content: A bucketful would be nice. Dr. Cuddy! Hi!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s completely unethical!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He was reckless with a patient.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He was right!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: But he didn’t know that. He needs at least some glimmer of humility.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why does he need that? Because other people have that? Why does he need to be like other people?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He needs to be less reckless.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well, you did it. He’s dismissing symptoms, looking for easy solutions, he’s in pain…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How much pain?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why? You know this is affecting him, don’t you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Telling him that he got his last case right won’t do anything to help him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’ll make him less depressed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Which might not help his leg.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But you don’t know!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Just let me run a PET scan on his parietal thalamic area to see if it’s sensing pain. If it is, the ketamine isn’t working anymore and he’s headed for a huge crash. If it’s not, the leg pain is my fault and I will tell him the truth.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Too tight?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: My parents think I’m crazy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, they don’t. They’re just worried about you, that’s all.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I’m not weird! It’s just that weird things keep happening to me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Slight pinch.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: If you make me better, do you think the aliens will leave me alone?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I don’t think they’re going to be bothering you for much longer.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: You lying again?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No. We figure this out, and everything’s going to be okay. Still with us? Pulmonary edema, stage two hypertensive crisis!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: What is happening?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wait outside! Get him oxygen and start him on an IV drip of sodium nitroprusside. Get them outside!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s in ICU, systolic is hovering around 170, I left instructions to lower it slowly so we don’t risk hypoperfusing his organs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tradeoff being that leaving his blood pressure that high risks stroke, MI, and blindness.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m open to suggestions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Solve the case. Kidneys could –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kidneys are clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell me he’s a mutant human hybrid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It is a bleeding disorder. Clancy tested positive for von Willenbrand’s.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I didn’t screw up. How could he clot on his own two out of three times?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe he cheated.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Right. Kids always cheat on their bleeding time tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She was being metaphorical. Trying to sound like me. I have no idea what you meant, but I could smell what the Rock was cooking.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I meant, he’s clotting right now and he’s in hypertensive crisis. Maybe the two are related. What if he was hypertensive the other two times that he clotted?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hypertensive crisis can activate clotting factors. Even someone low on von Willenbrand’s could theoretically clot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And the first time Clancy clotted he was all worked up recounting his alien abduction; he could have easily have been hypertensive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know I get worked up when I cut microchip tracking implants out of my neck.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sounds like a cheat to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, we get it. Okay, what’s the differential for a seven-year-old boy suffering multiple hypertensive crises?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We think the problem is in your son’s heart. We need to do a procedure called a transesophageal echo.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Okay, and that will fix his heart?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That will tell us where the problem is. Hopefully. Then we can fix him. Listen, this isn’t really part of my job, but… he’s worried that you think he’s crazy.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Well, isn’t he?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There are still plenty of other explanations for what’s going on. It’s important he knows you believe in him, even if you don’t.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s clean, his heart isn’t the problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why don’t I have hi-def in my office? I’m a department head!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There are no structural defects.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Valves are intact.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tissue characterization is impossible when the pixels are the size of Legos.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, this is what I’m talking about. Foreman, you’ve got to steal this thing for me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Let me ring up one of the homies.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The clearer the image, the clearer it is that there are no masses, no clots, no tears. The problem’s got to be somewhere else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re gonna need a bigger boat.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re wrong, House.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Think he’ll make us break into the IMAX before he admits it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right there. Left side, no movement. Well, don’t freeze it! Something’s not moving, how do you see something not move if nothing’s moving? I need the laser pointer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We don’t have a laser pointer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, why not? Who’s going to take us seriously if we don’t have a laser pointer? Right here! A few thousand myocytes not beating with the rest.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So you found an arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not an arrhythmia, that’s a no-rhythmia. Myocytes contract, these aren’t moving at all. Go get me those myocytes; I want to talk to them in my office.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How’s the kid doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Heart nearly exploded. Still beating, though. Most of it, anyway. Why do they bother putting age restrictions on these things when all you have to do is click, “Yes, I am 18”? Even a 17-year-old can figure that out.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What’s going on with the leg?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: First, tell me what’s going on with the boobs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you’re feeling pain –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re firmer.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s called an underwire. I want to get a PET scan of your brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think it’s hormones.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: As long as there’s no increased activity in the thalamus –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Looks to me like those puppies are going into the dairy business.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: -- Then the pain can be good. It could be muscle regenerating. After you work out, you get sore. Pain doesn’t mean the ketamine failed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guess I should be saying ‘mazel tov.’ Who gets to pass out the cigars?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m not pregnant. I need to get a PET scan of your brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Boy or girl? You got a name picked out?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m not pregnant!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My leg doesn’t hurt.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re in denial!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I’m not! Oh, you got me. If I thought my leg was deteriorating, don’t you think I’d want to take steps to prevent that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Here’s Clancy’s DNA, and here’s the DNA from the piece of that heart we just biopsied.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That is impossible. Run it again.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We already did. And once more after that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The genes from Clancy’s myocytes don’t match the genes from the rest of his body.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Alien DNA.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Anybody watch any X-Files that inspired an explanation?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There are ways DNA could become mutated. Extreme UV radiation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That much sun, he’d be dying with a healthy bronze glow.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Nitrous acid or ethidium bromide exposure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So first Daddy was a rapist, now he’s a chemist.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Various species of fungus have been proven mutagenic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not unless the kid’s been eating barrels of celery or living in Indonesia, or both.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is your leg hurting?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that question helping?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re leaning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re sitting.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re evading.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My head’s hurting. Please, someone give me a plausible, terrestrial explanation for this kid’s alien DNA.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We could search his home for toxins, fungals, and radiation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Who cares what caused it? A kid comes in with strep, we don’t conduct a search to see which classmate he got it from; we cure it. We know he’s got this stuff inside of him; let’s get a scalpel and cut it out.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where do we cut? Chances are it’s not just in his heart.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, we got lucky with the heart. Myocytes contract, we can see that these weren’t working. I don’t know how the hell we’re going to find it anywhere else.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What if we find the heart cells with the bad DNA and we tag them?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can you phrase that in the form of a metaphor?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s the same way we search for cancer. The bad DNA creates a unique protein on the surface of the affected cells. We create an antibody that recognizes only that protein and we flush it throughout his system, and the similar cells light up like light bulbs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, let’s do that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You have to tell him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He said he wasn’t in any pain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s lying.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course he’s lying.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We need another plan.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Don’t talk about it that way.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What way?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Plan. Sounds like we’re conspiring against him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m going to tell him.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you’re not.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then come up with a cunning plan, and fast.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s not nearly as delightful as she thinks she is.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: What’s this machine do?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Makes a lot of noise and it’s going to help us figure out what’s wrong with you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think House has lost his step?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s fine. There – clump of affected cells in the bone marrow of the femur. Explains the intermittent bleeding disorder.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: ‘Cause I don’t need to subject myself to House’s torture if there’s no upside.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m telling you, he’s fine. We missed some affected areas in his heart, explains the continuing hypertensive issues.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You said the last case really threw him, and now suddenly–

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I was wrong.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you changed your mind? Why? His brilliant ideas in this case have all been yours.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s the reason for him needing glasses, apparently it’s a symptom. Means the condition predates –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don’t change your mind without a reason. What do you know?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House didn’t blow the last case. Cuddy cured the guy using House’s idea. Cuddy and Wilson are trying to teach him some humility. Scan is complete. 3 hot spots but nothing in his brain. House’s original theory was right – it is not neurological.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Is he going to be able to walk?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His leg should be functional after some rehab.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Functional? What does that mean, he’ll be able to walk, but not run? He’ll have a limp?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If everything goes well he’ll walk, he’ll run; he’ll probably be even stronger than he is now. When we close him up, we’ll move over to his other leg, snake a catheter up through the femoral artery, and into his heart. Once the affected areas are removed, his normal tissue will step back in and do its job. He should have no more problems with his blood pressure. After confirming those areas are clear, we’ll start our final procedure. We’re going to insert a needle through the pupil and get rid of the abnormal cells in the retina.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Close your right eye. Can you see my face?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Yeah! It’s clear!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You can throw away your glasses. We got it all. Get some sleep, you’re going home tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You want to go for a run?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do you want?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I want you to run.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When did you become an enabler?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m enabling you to exercise. Vicodin blocks the pain, you get through your rehab, muscle strength increases, and pain decreases.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’d rather not become dependant on pain pills to get through my day.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re just like any other patient – running away from knowledge that won’t make you happy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m as happy as a pig in poop.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re scared the ketamine treatment’s wearing off. That it was just a tortuous window of the good life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What part of poop didn’t you understand?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How can you be so sure it isn’t just a sore muscle?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s my leg. We’ve known each other a long time.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re not always right, House. You’ve proven that lately.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: What’s happening to him?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s seizing. I need clonazepam!

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: I thought you got it all!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, yell at me, that’ll fix the kid.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Obviously we missed some foreign tissue. There’s something still in him.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The hallucinations and seizures indicate problems in the temporal lobe. Sorry, House, it is neurological. Looks like you’re wrong, again.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We didn’t miss anything. Brain scan was completely clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Our tag must not have penetrated the blood-brain barrier. Don’t use an IV this time; get it right into the brain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No cells are lighting up. His brain is clean. It is not neurological.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His symptoms are neurological; his condition has to be neurological!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His scan was clean, twice! It’s not there!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if it is there but didn’t show up on the scan? What if the tag just doesn’t work in his brain? Brain cells are structurally different, express a different protein.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So how are we going to find it?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where are we going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am going to think.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Send the kid home.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Make sure his blood pressure’s stabilized and send him home.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Like nothing ever happened?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We cured his bleeding disorder, removed all the damaged cells we could find.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We don’t know that we fixed anything, it’s only been a day. Maybe these symptoms come and go like the blood disorder.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s more probable that his remaining symptoms are just a nightmare.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He had a convulsion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: May be epilepsy, may be psychological, may be nothing. If the kid gets sick again it’ll give us another clue, we can start searching again. If he doesn’t, it doesn’t matter. Send him home.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House! You’re just giving up on this kid?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve got to know when to stop.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You don’t stop, you never stop, you just keep on going until you come up with something so insane that it’s usually right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Except on my last case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Don’t be pathetic. Just forget the last case. This kid obviously has something wrong with him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When did you develop such strong opinions about my patients? Last week you were convinced that my patient wasn’t sick, now you’re convinced this one is.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This one is a young boy. His parents are desperate. Just get together with your team, spend a few extra hours –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I guess we could amputate his left leg. That’s where we found most of it. Maybe we could just remove his affected eye completely.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you have reason to believe that that might help –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not going to start lopping off body parts, but it’s interesting that you’d give me the green light.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I just want you to do something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve been overly supportive this entire week. Either you’re hormonal or you’re guilt-ridden. And it’s too early in the pregnancy for this to be hormonal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m not pregnant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then what did you do wrong?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He had Addison’s, your last patient. You were right. I gave him one shot of cortisol and he woke up like Rip van Winkle.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, your mommy’s in such trouble. She’s such a liar! That’s why you don’t have a daddy. That’s why she had to –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How does one person end up with two different sets of DNA?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ve been through this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Our assumptions are faulty.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ve confirmed two different sets of DNA, we re-ran the sequence.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn’t say the lab work was faulty, I said our assumptions were faulty. We assumed he’s a person.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Of course, the aliens didn’t just visit him, they replaced him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you’re being silly. What if he’s not a person, what if he’s two persons?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not getting the metaphor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No metaphor. Chase, you said the mom used in vitro fertilization, right?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, they had trouble conceiving.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The kid was right all along, he was implanted with something. Back when he was really young, I mean really young, I mean twelve cells young. In vitro increases the likelihood of twinning.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But he doesn’t have a twin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not walking around. But in vitro fertilization costs about 25 grand a pop. So doctors implant about two to six embryos to make sure you get your money’s worth. Problem is, there’s not always enough bedrooms for all of the kiddies. Two brothers get stuck sharing, there’s no bunk beds, so they cuddle up to keep warm. They never untangle. He’s two people in one. It’s called chimerism.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unfortunately, his brother’s like a bad doubles partner. The guy just takes up space, gets in the way. Clancy’s body thinks that he’s going to put away the easy winners, but his brother just keeps swatting the balls into the net. We’ve got to get him off the court.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: So does that mean you can find the bad cells in his brain, or not?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, abandon the metaphor. Fine. Clancy thinks differently than his brother because he thinks. If we induce an alien abduction –

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Wait, what the hell are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The foreign DNA has got to be in a portion of your son’s brain that makes him believe that he’s being abducted. We stimulate those neurons with an electric probe; we can trick your son’s brain into hallucinating. And your son’s neurons will light up, and his brother’s cells will remain dark. Those are the ones we cut out.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: You’re talking about brain surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m talking about really cool brain surgery. One of your sons will die, but the taller one won’t be so annoying any more.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: So I have a twin?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not really. What’s on the card?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Light bulb.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start us out at ten.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: I’m not doing that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That was all me, kid. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re in motor function. Try two centimeters back.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: He lives inside me?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sort of.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Hee, that tickles! Stop tickling my feet!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re in sensory, getting closer.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What do you see on this one?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: Moon and stars. So I am kind of weird?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re all kind of weird.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: NO!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Clancy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ve got something.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What do you see?

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: The light. Here they come, I think.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Brain waves indicate mild hallucination. Neurons lighting up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any dark spots?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Area’s too fuzzy. Hallucination isn’t strong enough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, turn up the juice.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His blood pressure’s already 160/110. Any higher and –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Riding the short bus is better than not breathing. Take us to 100.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Area’s still too fuzzy to make any kind of distinction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Crank it up higher!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’ve already exceeded the preset maximum. Next step’s brain damage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re going to get you! They’re coming through the walls. They’re going to take you, torture you! You’ll never see your parents again.

utterance.speaker: Clancy
utterance.content: You got them.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yep, we got them all.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Close him up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Everything’s going to be normal again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You believe what Cuddy tried to pull?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She lied to me. She cured my patient with my diagnosis, then lied to me about it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That doesn’t sound like her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re right. It does sound like you, though.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What exactly did Cuddy tell you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing that your body language isn’t telling me right now. So, what was the plan? That I’d feel so humble by missing a case that I’d reevaluate my entire life, question nature, truth, and goodness and become Cameron?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Something like that. More that if we told you the truth; that you’d solved the case based on absolutely no medical proof, that you’d think you were God. And I was worried your wings would melt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: God doesn’t limp.
